results.snippet: Stephen H. Rhinesmith, on the job just a bit more than three months as coordinator of the President's U.S.-Soviet Exchange Initiative, has not been wasting any time.   He has already made two trips to Moscow that resulted in agreement in principle...

byline.original: By BARBARA GAMAREKIAN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Stephen H. Rhinesmith, on the job just a bit more than three months as coordinator of the President's U.S.-Soviet Exchange Initiative, has not been wasting any time. He has already made two trips to Moscow that resulted in agreement in principle on 13 educational and cultural exchange proposals, such as bringing a Soviet modern jazz group, the Ganelin Trio, here this summer on a 15-city tour. And he anticipates that his next trip, in June, will bring about agreement on exchanges of museum directors and ballet choreographers and on plans for a football and baseball exhibition. According to Dr. Rhinesmith, at a time when Washington and Moscow remain deeply divided over such issues as arms control and the Libyan raid, his trips have resulted in ''the broadest contact'' any American official has had with Soviet cultural and educational officials in the past decade.

headline.main: PILOT OF CHALLENGER IS BURIED WITH FULL RITES AT ARLINGTON

results.snippet: In the first public service for any of the seven crew members who perished aboard the space shuttle Challenger, Comdr. Michael J. Smith of the Navy was buried today at Arlington National Ceremony with full military honors.   Christa McAuliffe, a...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: In the first public service for any of the seven crew members who perished aboard the space shuttle Challenger, Comdr. Michael J. Smith of the Navy was buried today at Arlington National Ceremony with full military honors. Christa McAuliffe, a schoolteacher who was to have been the first private citizen to fly in space, was buried Thursday in a private ceremony in Concord, N.H. Services for the other crew members, both public and private, are to follow over the next few weeks. Today, a traditional funeral ceremony preceded the interment of Commander Smith, the pilot of the Challenger, which fell apart shortly after launching Jan. 28.

results.snippet: ''Sots'' art is a breed of art known here since the late 1970's, when the team of Russian artists known as Komar and Melamid clandestinely shipped to this country works that satirized the Russian bureaucracy. (The two coined the word ''Sots,''...
results.lead_paragraph: ''Sots'' art is a breed of art known here since the late 1970's, when the team of Russian artists known as Komar and Melamid clandestinely shipped to this country works that satirized the Russian bureaucracy. (The two coined the word ''Sots,'' short for ''Socialism,'' as an ironic equivalent for the American term ''Pop.'') In Sots art, banal symbols, icons and signs of the Soviet state are used as departure points for art that can be ironic, nostalgic or comic. Komar and Melamid are its most famous practitioners, but they have been joined here by a number of other Russian emigres.

results.snippet: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. This marred a welcome. Explain. 2. The Supreme Court ruled that committed opponents of the death penalty (may/may not) be barred from juries in capital cases....
results.lead_paragraph: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. This marred a welcome. Explain. 2. The Supreme Court ruled that committed opponents of the death penalty (may/may not) be barred from juries in capital cases. 3. The six people who emulated Adm. Robert E. Peary were the first ever to have their achievement confirmed. What was the achievement and how was it confirmed? 4. After winning won a plurality in the Austrian Presidential election, Kurt Waldheim said that the controversy over his war record had (helped/hindered) him in his campaign. 5. Wimmin, yuppies and yuck have finally made it. Explain. 6. Tens of thousands of people moved to higher ground in the Northwest, fearing a disastrous tsunami that turned out to be not dangerous at all, What is a tsunami? 7. It was a sentimental day at the Kentucky Derby, with 54-year-old Bill Shoemaker riding Ferdinand, a horse trained by 73-year-old Charlie Whittingham, to victory. How many derbies had Shoemaker and Whittingham each won previously? 8. Although the tax bill passed by the Senate calls for only two basic rates, 15 percent and 27 percent, some upper-income taxpayers may find a part of their earnings taxed at (29/ 32/35/40) percent because of special provisions to keep the wealthy from reaping a windfall. 9. There were whooping, yelling and chanting at the ceremony in which the Rev. Donald E. Pelotte was ordained a Bishop of the Roman Catholic Church.

results.snippet: SINCE word of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant disaster reached the West, one of the dozen radio sets mounted inside a tiny, white-trimmed brick building on Main Street in Newington has been trained on Radio Moscow, though what Radio Moscow does...
results.lead_paragraph: SINCE word of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant disaster reached the West, one of the dozen radio sets mounted inside a tiny, white-trimmed brick building on Main Street in Newington has been trained on Radio Moscow, though what Radio Moscow does not say may be more interesting than what it does. The chief radio operator, Charles Bender, does not expect to learn much about the accident this way. ''The Soviet Government has a very restrictive system,'' Mr. Bender said. ''We monitor Radio Moscow, but all we hear is the party line.'' Exactly what Radio Moscow is saying, and not saying, about what is believed to be the worst nuclear accident in history is of keen interest to Mr. Bender, and to the rest of the world as well.

results.snippet: OUR FAMILY CHRISTMAS CARD THIS YEAR showed the five of us - my husband, Steve Bethel; our children, Audrey, Charlie and Willy, and me - lined up on our couch, beside the tree we had just cut down. Three good-looking and healthy children; two...

byline.original: By Joyce Maynard; Joyce Maynard writes a syndicated column, ''Domestic Affairs.'' Her most recent book is ''Camp-Out,'' a children's book written with her husband, Steve Bethel

results.lead_paragraph: OUR FAMILY CHRISTMAS CARD THIS YEAR showed the five of us - my husband, Steve Bethel; our children, Audrey, Charlie and Willy, and me - lined up on our couch, beside the tree we had just cut down. Three good-looking and healthy children; two parents, married to each other. Snowdrifts outside, and a big black dog - just out of camera range - licking our feet. There is even an American flag that my sons like to use for parades, propped in the background. Our arms are around each other, and we are (except for Charlie, who sucks his thumb) laughing.

results.snippet: Coffin of Ronald E. McNair being carried to the South Carolina State House in Columbia. Citizens paid their last respects to the South Carolina native who is to be buried in his hometown of Lake City. (UPI)
results.lead_paragraph: Coffin of Ronald E. McNair being carried to the South Carolina State House in Columbia. Citizens paid their last respects to the South Carolina native who is to be buried in his hometown of Lake City. (UPI)

results.snippet: There's a theme for the weekend,'' David L. Wolper was saying. ''The theme is remember, rejoice, renew. We're going to be reflecting about how everyone came to this country. We're going to rejoice by having a great party. And we're going to renew...

byline.original: By Jeffrey Schmalz; Jeffrey Schmalz is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: There's a theme for the weekend,'' David L. Wolper was saying. ''The theme is remember, rejoice, renew. We're going to be reflecting about how everyone came to this country. We're going to rejoice by having a great party. And we're going to renew everything the Statue of Liberty stands for.'' Mr. Wolper, the television and movie producer, has been recruited to do for New York and the statue what he did for Los Angeles and the flamboyant opening and closing ceremonies of the Olympic Games in 1984. Rain or shine, Liberty Weekend '86, a huge series of celebrations under Mr. Wolper's direction, will transfigure the New York and New Jersey sides of the harbor from Thursday night, July 3, to Sunday night, July 6. Mr. Wolper was favored by the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation because while other producers might talk in terms of dozens, or even hundreds, he tends to think in terms of thousands.

results.snippet: In the church his parents brought him to as a child, Dr. Ronald E. McNair was eulogized today as an example to children. And afterward, in a newly cleared plot surrounded by the fields where he picked cotton as a boy, the remains of the Challenger...

byline.original: By DUDLEY CLENDINEN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: In the church his parents brought him to as a child, Dr. Ronald E. McNair was eulogized today as an example to children. And afterward, in a newly cleared plot surrounded by the fields where he picked cotton as a boy, the remains of the Challenger astronaut were finally laid to rest. His journey - from birth in a small wooden house with no plumbing, through the segregated school system of his formative years here, to an engineering degree and a doctorate in physics, to research in laser physics at the Hughes Laboratory outside Los Angeles, to acceptance in the astronaut program, to his flight around the earth in the space shuttle Challenger in 1984, to his death in its explosion this January - required 35 years.

results.lead_paragraph: Additional titles of interest: TROUBLE IN BUGLAND: A Collection of Inspector Mantis Mysteries. By William Kotzwinkle. Illustrated by Joe Servello. Godine.

results.snippet: Most Americans think of China as the land of the bicycle.   Late next year, they may have to adjust that image, if, as proposed, a United States-built communications satellite is launched into space aboard a Chinese Long March-3 rocket from a space...

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Most Americans think of China as the land of the bicycle. Late next year, they may have to adjust that image, if, as proposed, a United States-built communications satellite is launched into space aboard a Chinese Long March-3 rocket from a space center set in the hilly woodlands of southern Sichuan. If the launching succeeds, a second privately owned United States satellite will follow in 1988. According to Chinese officials, up to nine other nations have shown interest in similar deals. The memorandum of agreement announced last week by Teresat Inc. of Houston and the China Great Wall Industry Corporation, an agency of the Astronautics Ministry, came against the background of uncertainty in the United States space industry following four major launching failures in the past 16 weeks, including the loss of the space shuttle Challenger Jan. 28.

headline.main: Stunt Plane Crashes, Killing 2 From NASA

results.snippet: A stunt plane crashed while performing maneuvers Saturday, killing an astronaut candidate and a NASA engineer, officials said.
results.lead_paragraph: A stunt plane crashed while performing maneuvers Saturday, killing an astronaut candidate and a NASA engineer, officials said.

headline.main: ULTIMATE SURVIVAL: DESERT DREAMERS BUILD A MAN-MADE WORLD

results.snippet: ON a high plateau in the Arizona desert, construction has begun on a $30 million project designed to test the feasibility of self-sustaining manned bases on the Moon or Mars - or on an earth ravaged by nuclear war.   When the prototype ''Biosphere...
results.lead_paragraph: ON a high plateau in the Arizona desert, construction has begun on a $30 million project designed to test the feasibility of self-sustaining manned bases on the Moon or Mars - or on an earth ravaged by nuclear war. When the prototype ''Biosphere II'' structure is completed in 1989, its developers say, eight volunteers will be sealed inside it for two years, cut off from everything except sunlight. They will become part of an intricate ecosystem that includes miniature oceans, rain forests, marshlands and deserts, all contained in an airtight shell of steel and glass. Everything in this manmade world will be recycled. Carbon dioxide exhaled by humans will be used by plants, while oxygen given off by the plants will revitalize the air for human breathing. Human wastes will provide fertilizer for land crops and feed algae, bacteria and water plants, which in turn will feed fish.

headline.main: LAWYERS REST CASES IN JOHNSON TRIAL

results.snippet: Both sides in the Johnson estate trial rested their cases yesterday amid reports that an out-of-court settlement was being negotiated.   The trial involves a battle over the $500 million will of the late J. Seward Johnson, heir to the Johnson and...
results.lead_paragraph: Both sides in the Johnson estate trial rested their cases yesterday amid reports that an out-of-court settlement was being negotiated. The trial involves a battle over the $500 million will of the late J. Seward Johnson, heir to the Johnson and Johnson pharmaceutical fortune. Lawyers for his widow, Barbara, who is virtually his only heir, and for his six children by two previous marriages, who are contesting the will, were scheduled to deliver their summations to the jury today.
